summary: Head and neck cancer is a term for cancers that develop in the mouth, nose and sinuses, salivary glands, and throat and voice box (larynx). Most head and neck cancers are squamous cell cancers, which begin in the moist tissues lining the head and neck. The cancer cells can spread into deeper tissue as the cancer grows.
causes: HPV infection (for cancers in the tonsils and base of the tongue)
Exposure to wood dusts or certain other toxic substances at work (for upper throat, nose, and sinus cancers)
Radiation exposure to the head and neck (for salivary gland cancer)
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection (for upper throat and salivary gland cancers)
risk_factors: History of head or neck cancer
symptoms: Sore in the mouth or throat that does not heal and may be painful
Sore throat that does not go away
Change or hoarseness in the voice
diagnosis: Biopsy or other procedure to collect cells
